Detailed Description

A file reader that extracts localizable data out of an XML file and provides an interface for both audio player functions as well as any other class that displays localizable GUI strings.

Usually, I use this class together with two other classes: The GameMaster contains all user preferences (like the current language) and provides a connection to this class. A second class connects to the GameMaster and provides a simplified method to return a string:

    internal string s (string id) { ... }

This second class then acts as an intermediate, with all other classen in the game inheriting from it (instead of MonoBehaviour). Like this, the GameMaster can provide the correct language, and all GameObjects inheriting from the second class get easy access to localised strings, without having to fuss around with language codes.

This version has been heavily reworked from the first version. Things might fail, as I was trying to get all the old cruft out. Most likely the whole thing could still be greatly improved. Any suggestions are welcome and can be posted over at https://github.com/xeophin/UnityTranslator. Feel free to fork the project and build upon it.

Warning:
This code will only work with an XML String file of version 1.1 and up, since it collects the list of available languages from it.
A later version of this class might take the GetText and GetAudio methods apart, in order to keep performance.
Version:
2.0
Author:
Kaspar Manz

string  id,
string @  group,
string  lang

Creates the XPath to a node.

Returns:
A string with the complete path.
Parameters:
whatWhat element shall be selected, i.e text or audio.
idThe ID of the string.
groupThe group in which the string resides in.
langThe language in which the string should be accessed.
Deprecated:
Should not be used anymore ... wasn't very useful in the first place.

Definition at line 241 of file Translator.cs.

string [] Translator.GetText ( XmlNode  element,
string  lang 
)

This method takes a XmlNode and tries to extract the text with the correct language.

This method could actually help to reduce the cruft of this class, since it would be easy to get out the XML elements based on their IDs and let this method handle the actual extracting based on the language.

Also, this helps splitting up the XML files – now any other class can easily parse it's own files and then hand the XmlNode to this method.

Parameters:
langA System.String defining in which language the string is supposed to be returned.
elementA XmlNode that contains the extracted strings.
Returns:
A System.String[].

Definition at line 187 of file Translator.cs.

string [] Translator.GetText ( string  id )

Retrieves the string by its ID. Does not respect any language settings and just returns the first valid text or audio element it will find, no matter what language.

Parameters:
idThe ID of the string as a System.String.
Returns:
An array of System.String[] containing both the actual text as well as the path to the audio file. Returns "null" when it doesn't find anything. Check your log to see what has not been found.
Exceptions:
NullReferenceException

Definition at line 108 of file Translator.cs.

string [] Translator.GetText ( string  id,
string  language 
)

Retrieves the string by its ID and language.

Parameters:
idThe ID of the text as a System.String.
languageThe group name as a System.String.
Returns:
An array of System.String[] containing both the actual text as well as the path to the audio file. Returns "null" when it doesn't find anything. Check your log to see what has not been found.

This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

Definition at line 64 of file Translator.cs.

TextAsset Translator.stringFile

The path to the XML file containing the localized strings.

The path within Unity is relativ to the project folder and not to the Assets directory (i.e. "Assets/localized.xml").
